cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:09): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: discussion about priorities and schedule for things in writing-modes
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:09): 72af1cb61d47fcc5d18402bf3d1c147d: 25812bf456959aa5f28dc570f341a3ba: writing modes, following from last week.
ac3b293515e969dace7717d9104ad079 (19:09): mutes due to close thunderstorm here
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:09): 72af1cb61d47fcc5d18402bf3d1c147d: I missed the last minutes of last week.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:10): befddef7b56a6caf71fa21f2235a8111: this is Fantasai's proposal. My proposal is different.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:10): .. I do not see the need to compare the bidi algo.

cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:10): ... for the text orientation, you need a way to distiguish for different unicode point, which are going to rotate and the ones that are going to remain upright.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:11): ... if you look at figure 7 in the writing mode spec (link above).
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:11): ... this is the problem that text orientation is trying to address. You have content that is rendered in different directions depending on context.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:12): ... 2011 is rendered upright but also rotated right.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:12): ... If you have normal punctuation ascii characters for example, it is not clear what direction they should have in all cases.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:13): ... For emoticon, for example, the orientation may be different depending on context (e.g., in english text or in japanese text).
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:13): ... My proposal was that for ambiguous characters, they would take the orientation of the surrounding text.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:14): florianr: it seems that what your propose is close to what 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d is proposing.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:14): befddef7b56a6caf71fa21f2235a8111: yes, but I do not see the need to bring in BiDi to resolve this simpler problem.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:15): florian: if you want to drop the introduction, that is fine.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:15): befddef7b56a6caf71fa21f2235a8111: BiDi has nesting behaviors.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:15): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: in some cases, the context is ambiguous, and BiDi has already solutions for resolving ambiguous contexts.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:16): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: I could rewrite without using the BiDi reference but use the same algorithm.
3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d (19:16): ACTION 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: rewrite proposal to not reference bidi because it's confusing
22813b6f9b851d152e2f2d99116de592 (19:16): noticed an ACTION. Trying to create it.
22813b6f9b851d152e2f2d99116de592 (19:16): Created ACTION-338 - Rewrite proposal to not reference bidi because it's confusing [on Elika Etemad - due 2011-07-20].
0a6e04acaaef9f5ff2575f489d8c421d (19:16): It seems that the same ambiguities arise don't they?
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:17): befddef7b56a6caf71fa21f2235a8111: starting the explanation by details of the BiDi algorithm is obtuse.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:17): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: is the action item satisfactory.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:18): 72af1cb61d47fcc5d18402bf3d1c147d: the issue is about the algorithm, not the word BiDi
0a6e04acaaef9f5ff2575f489d8c421d (19:18): So John thinks some other algorithm applies??
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:18): 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d: I thought you wanted the same behavior. I do not understand what you want.

cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:19): szilles: I sent a message last night which suggested that using the script TR instead of the BiDi TR would make more sense. Simpler, covers a number of the cases that befddef7b56a6caf71fa21f2235a8111 wanted to cover.
cf0698af7ff0db50207842515fbe4f5b (19:19): ... it is a simpler description. It is not algorithmic unfortunately. There are problems with matching code.
